text: I found an old Maude interface I had done. It's a bit clunky as you have to parse the results from an XML file. Also to properly interface with Julia you'd have to generate Maude code. Are there any mature rewriting software that would be easier to interface with?

elements.text: I found an old Maude interface I had done. It's a bit clunky as you have to parse the results from an XML file. Also to properly interface with Julia you'd have to generate Maude code. Are there any mature rewriting software that would be easier to interface with?

text: There’s native Julia rewriting functionality in SymbolicUtils.jl. There are also Julia interfaces Reduce.jl and Maxima.jl. What are you looking for?

elements.text: There’s native Julia rewriting functionality in SymbolicUtils.jl. There are also Julia interfaces Reduce.jl and Maxima.jl. What are you looking for?

text: I'm aware of SymbolicUtils, Reduce and Maxima. Maude is more mature and has more features like equational logic. I'm not sure if Maxima or Reduce support user types.

elements.text: I'm aware of SymbolicUtils, Reduce and Maxima. Maude is more mature and has more features like equational logic. I'm not sure if Maxima or Reduce support user types.

text: I hate to say it but maybe Julia is not the best tool for this kind of thing? Or maybe you just need to convert Maude rules into SymbolicUtils rules?

elements.text: I hate to say it but maybe Julia is not the best tool for this kind of thing? Or maybe you just need to convert Maude rules into SymbolicUtils rules?

text: I'm trying to manipulate Julia code and looking for complementary solutions to the existing rewriting libraries. Essentially, I would do the same with Maude that Reduce.jl does with Reduce (ie convert Julia to Maude, process it and convert it back). I was just wondering if there were more convenient interfaces or software.

elements.text: I'm trying to manipulate Julia code and looking for complementary solutions to the existing rewriting libraries. Essentially, I would do the same with Maude that Reduce.jl does with Reduce (ie convert Julia to Maude, process it and convert it back). I was just wondering if there were more convenient interfaces or software.

text: Manipulate Julia code in what way?

elements.text: Manipulate Julia code in what way?

text: <https://egraphs-good.github.io/> is more what I'm looking for. You can see some of the applications on the website. I'm interested in using it for symbolic statistics and optimizing linear algebra expressions.

elements.text: is more what I'm looking for. You can see some of the applications on the website. I'm interested in using it for symbolic statistics and optimizing linear algebra expressions.

text: That looks interesting. How do they use symbolic manipulation? Do they call out to an external package? Are you aware of Julia's metaprogramming capabilities?

elements.text: That looks interesting. How do they use symbolic manipulation? Do they call out to an external package? Are you aware of Julia's metaprogramming capabilities?

text: Yes, I know about metaprogramming. E-graphs are an efficient data structure to store all the possible equivalent rewrites of an expression. You can then search this structure to optimize for a given objective like AST size, for example.

elements.text: Yes, I know about metaprogramming. E-graphs are an efficient data structure to store all the possible equivalent rewrites of an expression. You can then search this structure to optimize for a given objective like AST size, for example.

text: Here is a blog post about E-graphs in Julia: <https://www.philipzucker.com/egraph-1/>

attachments.title: E-graphs in Julia (Part I)
attachments.text: E-graphs are the data structure that efficiently compute with equalities between terms. It can be used to prove equivalences for equational reasoning, but also to find equational rewrites, which is useful for program transformations or algebraic simplification.
attachments.fallback: Hey There Buddo!: E-graphs in Julia (Part I)
